Entry.1: Final Inspection by O.C. - Left Liverpool 2 p.m. Paraded through City and Reviewed at Domain. Spent night at showground
Entry.2: Marched to Orient . Grand send-off -fine spectacle -left harbour at 1.30 p.m. -spent good afternoon - slightly sick at night. Slept on deck in hammock.
Entry.3:
Continued journey -

pleasant day -pleasant trip -- boxing on board -sighted Victoria about 6 p.m.
Entry.4: Arrived Port Melbourne 4 a.m. - wrote letters - granted leave 11 a.m. till midnight -walked through City -luncheon and dinner at Sargent - trip to St Kilda -caught in dust and rain storm -game of billiards -Pantomime at night (Mother Goose) -very good -riot - return to Osterley.
Entry.5:
Bad news -no

leave. Exceptionally enthusiastic send-off by Melbourne people. "We do not like Melbourne or its people nearly as good as Sydney -but we shall always thank and remember them on the occasion of our leavingPort Melbourne"- anchored out in the stream.
Entry.6: A.M.C. take up my duties -self in charge of Ward -3 patients -high price of refreshments.
Entry.7: Continued good weather. Instruction by Capt Smith Osier - 10 a.m. & 3 p.m. -fracture and bandaging -letters.
Entry.8: Arrived Outer Harbour (Adelaide) - fine wharf. Leave of 3 hours - visited P.O. & restaurant - met Miss McDonald & Miss Bray - left for Fremantle at 6 p.m.
Entry.9:
One week on water. Lift-belt parade -instruction - meet Sydney High

Boys - wash clothes.
Entry.10: Sabbath - church parade - weather still fine - spar with Tommy Watson -letters.
Entry.11: Weather much rougher - sighted land after 3 days - Albany & the Leewin. Instruction in Hemorrhage.
Entry.12:
Arrived at Fremantle - general leave.

Took train to Perth - pleasant trip - good opinion of Perth - run in Motor Car through Kings Park & back to City - fine sights of Swan River etc - excellent roads - swimming baths-- good meal - return to vessel - hearty farewell - courageous act of last man aboard - last glimpse of dear old Australia.
Entry.13:
Anniversary of our native land.

Payday (10 days at 1/-). Instruction.
Entry.14: Flying fishes - shark -boxing at night - change of duties - 'Hemorrhage lecture' etc.
Entry.15: Beginning to feel heat of tropics - lecture by Capt. Jenks,'Discipline & morality'. First day of Boxing Tourney - F.E. Beaurepaire.
Entry.16: Fortnight on ocean - Lifebelt drill - Weather hotter - ship inspection -letters. Very good bout in Tourney. Lecture on Fractures.
Entry.17: Sunday -first rain since leaving Sydney - peculiar clouds & weather -abandon our bunks on deck - calm.
Entry.18:
More rain -2,200 miles from Australia,

weather rough - nothing of importance.
Entry.19: Still rough -concert by Australian Follies (Passengers) -imitation of Tivoli Follies - very popular entertainment - speech by Col. Holland.
Entry.20: Bad cold - weather hot & sultry - usual duties - good boxing bouts - glorious Eastern sunset - everyone in good humour.
Entry.21:
Fine day -arrive in Harbour of Colombo at 7 a.m. -boat besieged by natives - peculiar boats & propulsion - great many big boats in harbour including Australian Hospital Ship 'Karoola' on way to Sydney - leave stopped - route march instead - slow passage ashore - march through main streets to "barracks"- pestered greatly by natives - two rides in rickshaws - native thieves - peculiar

-ities of children - also buildings - arrival at Barracks - cheap fruit etc. - fine native soldiers-- canteen-- lemonade, fruit, biscuits - return to wharf - troops break lines - all the boys have head-aches - mediocre impression of Colombo.Left harbour at 10 p.m. for last stage of voyage.
Entry.22:
Once more out on the briny - read "The Tangled Skein"(Orczy) - lecture by Returned

Nurse on Hospital Duties in Egypt - continuation of Boxing Tourney (semi-finals).
Entry.23: Weather still good -second issue of "Osterley Keystone" - washing-day.
Entry.24: Third week of voyage completed - one more week to go - Church Parade - good deal of reading -weather rougher -many sick.
Entry.25: Sighted first land since Colombo - in the morning, Islands of Socotra & the "Brothers" - and in the evening N. East Africa and Cape Guardafui. Finals of Boxing -good bouts -passed two ships.
Entry.26: Read "One Day"(Glyn) - weather good but hot. Rifle & Physical drill competitions amongst troops - Tug-o-war won by Artillery - letters.
Entry.27: In Gulf of Aden - sighted land throughout the day. Arabian Coast & Islands -passed three or four vessels. Lanternlecture by Ship's Captain- practice firing with ship's gun.
Entry.28: Passed "Twelve Apostles"Islands -and many ships - Red Sea - letters - first and only death - burial at sea - impressive ceremony.
Entry.29: Red Sea - coolest part of voyage - preparations - stewards concert. Farewell speech by skipper.
Entry.30: Gulf of Suez - nearest to land since Colombo - "boys"pleased because of end of journey - great weather.
Entry.31:
Arrived Suez 6 a.m. -impressed by Port etc - final preparations - disembarkment -

dry rations -very poor trains - final cheers given to boat crew & passengers and last sight of good old Osterley. Travelling very slow -pestered "en route"by natives - shook hands with Indian Sikh who praised Australians - oranges & lollies - arrived Zeitoun 1 a.m.

Monday
Entry.32:
Transport of kit to camp -bed 2.30 a.m.

Feb 14th
Parade 9 a.m. -address and routine orders by O.C.



(Cont.)

Again meet Sgt Roberts - survey of camp - breakfast (24 hours without recognition) - easy day - trip to Cairo via Heliopolis - fine trams and trains - Cairo good and bad points - slums - natives - Y.M.C.A. -coinage - tea in town - bully beef & biscuits.
Entry.33:
Parade 6.30. Tomatoes for breakfast -raining all day -Cairo in afternoon -met Quinert, Barnes

Smith. Tea at Y.M.C.A. - Billiard saloon - post cards to Sydney.

End of diary - future notes of interest follow on from here.



(1)

Virgins Tree and Marys Well
Entry.35: Two miles from camp -Obelisk 60 ft high -composed of 1 piece of solid marble -covered with hieroglyphics.
Entry.36:
Cemetery.
One mile from Zeitoun Camp -Graves hundreds and also thousands of years old – shallow -tombstones to cover graves – family tombs – beads and valuables with bodies – search.
Entry.37:
Egyptian Bazaar
Description - good and bad articles - cosmopolitan - dealing.
Entry.38:
Garry Drive (Fred C. & self).
One hour 10P.T. -Sultan's Palace -magnificent building -Guard -slums -Falling of horses -Driver's demands.
Entry.39:
Kursaal
Revue "Smile up"- decent theatre - short program ( 2 hours) - poor show - badly produced & set - poor dressing - amateurish -songs and dialogue in English (chiefly) & also French.

(7)

Ostrich Farm (Mar 2nd)
One mile from Camp -composed of mud walls, resembling native village -site of old farm - Young and old birds & eggs -male birds black.

(7)cont.

"The Lookout"- used by signallers -fine collection of pigeons.

(8)

Change of Camp
Zeitoun to Ismailia -on Mar 5th 1916. Left Zeitoun 6 a.m. - train to Cairo Station - thence to Ismailia which is on Suez Canal (approx. 100 miles from Cairo) - good journey - cultivation & irrigation of Nile - Ismailia fine little town

(8)

march of 4 or 5 miles to camp - very tired - slept on desert under waggon - very cold -unsettled - Ferry Post & Gadging Camps.

(9)

Further Change of Camp (6th Feb)
Ferry Post to Moaska - Moasca Camp situated near township of Ismailia near railway line -all hope of joining our unit has vanished.

(9)

Attached to 7th Fld Amb -Queenslanders chiefly -no tents -food good -O.C. Fair -plenty of work with very little Recreation or amusement - boys downhearted - troops daily passing in trains -big movement apparent. Rumours of going to France very shortly. Cannot send letters (or "receive them"). Active Service in Reality - washing inMess Tin (about ½pt of water) -- sleeping out - wet blankets. "Are we downhearted?" No!

(10)

7th Field Ambulance
Permanently & officially attached to 7th F. Amb on Mar 8th - comrades & self in B section under Major Brennan D.S.O. 7th composed chiefly of Queenslanders and S. Australians -popular officers -good food -well satisfied -letters farther off than ever - struck censoring of our own letters. Colours of unit -Chocolate square turned on end, as .

Officially announced
Entry.40:
by officers of 7th about our going to France - Respirators.

Diary of Voyage No. 2 - B. Section - 7th Fld. Amb.
Entry.42: Inspection by O.C. -march with full kit - break camp at Moascar - Entrain & leave Moascar 11.30 p.m.
Entry.43: Monotonous train journey to Alexandria - arrive at port 7 a.m. - embark on A.41 (S.S. Minneapolis) (destination unknown) - ship overcrowded -food poor -hammocks issued.
Entry.44:
Commenced voyage about 6.30 a.m. - Mediterranean - constant wearing of life-belts - "band selections"- ship's canteen gives us our

first fair deal for many weeks -apparent dangers of submarines etc - picket duties on horse-decks. Duties, distinction marks etc of French Officers & soldiers read out by Adjutant. Lights out 5.30 p.m.

March 15th
Sea much rougher - with constant rain - picket duties - Minneapolis fitted with two large guns (one fore & one aft) and two Lewis Machine-guns or rifles -

latest pattern - "Our troopship the first to leave Egypt for the European part of the business."
Entry.45: Picket duties. Ship inspection - band -letters -very rough and cold weather -suffering from cold -bed 5.30 p.m. (record).
Entry.46:
Pass Malta - hair-cut (Barber who visited the "old joint"at Balmain) -physical drill and Inspection -

weather much better.
Entry.47: Pass C. Bon (Algeria) and later sight of S. Coast of Sardinia. Inoculation - arm very bad - food worse than ever.
Entry.48: Pass Island of Corsica (birthplace of Napoleon) - arrive at Marseilles 2.30 p.m. - Naturally fortified port - fine shipping centre - spend the night on board - sleep on wooden seat 9" wide.
Entry.49:
Unload



vessel -deprivation of cameras - arm much better - boys anxious to get away from steamers.
